info.name: Form.io API Documentation
info.description:
Form.io not only serves as a Form platform for your Serverless applications, but can also serve as a complete ***REST API*** platform as well. This is becasue everything that happens within Form.io, does so through the use of a robust REST API call within the form platform.

What makes Form.io unique is that all of the APIs created from the schema of the Form iteself. As you drag-and-drop new components onto a form, you are essentially defining a JSON schema that is also used to generate the REST API needed to support that form.

The following documentation outlines a complete walkthrough of using the Form.io API platform.

item.name: 1.) Authentication

request.description:
Since the Form.io API's are entirely **Stateless**, you can actually logout by simply NOT including a JWT Token in the header of the next request.

We also provide a dediated API method for logging out, which will set the ```x-jwt-token``` header to empty which will force the application to remove it from its local cache. This essentially logs you out of the application you are using as well as the API.

originalRequest.description:
Since the Form.io API's are entirely **Stateless**, you can actually logout by simply NOT including a JWT Token in the header of the next request.

We also provide a dediated API method for logging out, which will set the ```x-jwt-token``` header to empty which will force the application to remove it from its local cache. This essentially logs you out of the application you are using as well as the API.

header.name: Access-Control-Allow-Origin
header.description: Specifies a URI that may access the resource. For requests without credentials, the server may specify '*' as a wildcard, thereby allowing any origin to access the resource.

header.name: Connection
header.description: Options that are desired for the connection

header.name: Content-Length
header.description: The length of the response body in octets (8-bit bytes)

header.name: Content-Type
header.description: The mime type of this content

header.name: Date
header.description: The date and time that the message was sent

header.name: ETag
header.description: An identifier for a specific version of a resource, often a message digest

header.name: Server
header.description: A name for the server

header.name: Vary
header.description: Tells downstream proxies how to match future request headers to decide whether the cached response can be used rather than requesting a fresh one from the origin server.

header.name: X-Powered-By
header.description: Specifies the technology (ASP.NET, PHP, JBoss, e.g.) supporting the web application (version details are often in X-Runtime, X-Version, or X-AspNet-Version)

header.name: x-jwt-token
header.description: Custom header

request.description:
Typically the first thing you will want to do when using the Form.io API is to authenticate as your Form.io user you created when you signed up for the https://form.io service.

This user serves as the SuperAdmin for all of the projects as well as all of the submissions/data within those projects. Using your Form.io account, you can control all aspects of all of your projects created within Form.io

In order to login to Form.io, you are actually going to submit the Login form which is provided by the Form.io project @ https://formio.form.io. That's right... Form.io actually uses its own internal project to provide authentication into itself... INCEPTION!

To login to https://form.io, simply provide the following API call.

originalRequest.description:
Typically the first thing you will want to do when using the Form.io API is to authenticate as your Form.io user you created when you signed up for the https://form.io service.

This user serves as the SuperAdmin for all of the projects as well as all of the submissions/data within those projects. Using your Form.io account, you can control all aspects of all of your projects created within Form.io

In order to login to Form.io, you are actually going to submit the Login form which is provided by the Form.io project @ https://formio.form.io. That's right... Form.io actually uses its own internal project to provide authentication into itself... INCEPTION!

To login to https://form.io, simply provide the following API call.

header.name: x-jwt-token
header.description: Custom header

item.description:
In order to authenticate with Form.io you must first target the form which you wish to authenticate against. Every project within Form.io will have its own user login form which you can use to generate the JWT Token necessary to authenticate yourself against the Form.io API.

The website https://form.io is no exception. We use our own Form.io project to create the authentication capability within Form.io. The URL for this form is as follows.

```
https://formio.form.io/user/login
```

Posting your login credentials will authenticate you within the Form.io project and give you access to create your own Projects. It does this through the use of a JWT Token, which you can see within the response header as.

```
x-jwt-token
```

This token is then needed for any other requests being made so that those requests can be authenticated.

item.name: 2.) Project API

request.description: Returns the project access information for your application to hide and show certain elements based on the returned values.

originalRequest.description: Returns the project access information for your application to hide and show certain elements based on the returned values.

request.description:
This will create a new project within Form.io. You can provide the template JSON file. For example, if you wish to create a new project using the ToDo application, you would provide the following project.json file for the create template.

```
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/formio/formio-app-todo/master/src/project.json
```

originalRequest.description:
This will create a new project within Form.io. You can provide the template JSON file. For example, if you wish to create a new project using the ToDo application, you would provide the following project.json file for the create template.

```
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/formio/formio-app-todo/master/src/project.json
```

request.description:
Now that you have a project, the next step is to create some accounts within that project which you will be able to log into. The way that Form.io works, is that each project serves as sandboxed database, where all the Users and Administrators are simply ***submissions*** within the ***User*** and ***Admin*** resource respectively.

To create a new administrator, you simply need to submit the ***Admin*** form with the data required by the fields added to that resource.

originalRequest.description:
Now that you have a project, the next step is to create some accounts within that project which you will be able to log into. The way that Form.io works, is that each project serves as sandboxed database, where all the Users and Administrators are simply ***submissions*** within the ***User*** and ***Admin*** resource respectively.

To create a new administrator, you simply need to submit the ***Admin*** form with the data required by the fields added to that resource.

request.description:
To get a specific form, you simply send the ```GET``` command to the Form URL which can be described as follows.

```
GET - https://myproject.form.io/myform
```

originalRequest.description:

```

```

request.description:
Form Tagging allows you to tag forms that should be grouped together. This is very useful within your application if you wish to create sections where users only see certain forms within your project.

You can search which forms have a certain tag by using the following.

```
https://myproject.form.io/myform?tags=testing
```

If you need to search for forms that have multiple tags, then you can use the ```__in``` modifier and then add all the tags with commas.

```
https://myproject.form.io/myform?tags__in=testing,hello
```

originalRequest.description:
Form Tagging allows you to tag forms that should be grouped together. This is very useful within your application if you wish to create sections where users only see certain forms within your project.

You can search which forms have a certain tag by using the following.

```
https://myproject.form.io/myform?tags=testing
```

If you need to search for forms that have multiple tags, then you can use the ```__in``` modifier and then add all the tags with commas.

```
https://myproject.form.io/myform?tags__in=testing,hello
```

header.name: Access-Control-Allow-Origin
header.description: Specifies a URI that may access the resource. For requests without credentials, the server may specify '*' as a wildcard, thereby allowing any origin to access the resource.

header.name: Access-Control-Expose-Headers
header.description: Lets a server whitelist headers that browsers are allowed to access.

header.name: Connection
header.description: Options that are desired for the connection

header.name: Content-Encoding
header.description: The type of encoding used on the data.

header.name: Content-Length
header.description: The length of the response body in octets (8-bit bytes)

header.name: Content-Range
header.description: Where in a full body message this partial message belongs

header.name: Content-Type
header.description: The mime type of this content

header.name: Date
header.description: The date and time that the message was sent

header.name: Link
header.description: Used to express a typed relationship with another resource, where the relation type is defined by RFC 5988

header.name: Range-Unit
header.description: Custom header

header.name: Server
header.description: A name for the server

header.name: Vary
header.description: Tells downstream proxies how to match future request headers to decide whether the cached response can be used rather than requesting a fresh one from the origin server.

header.name: X-Powered-By
header.description: Specifies the technology (ASP.NET, PHP, JBoss, e.g.) supporting the web application (version details are often in X-Runtime, X-Version, or X-AspNet-Version)

header.name: x-jwt-token
header.description: Custom header

request.description:
You can create a new form within your project by using the ```POST``` message to the ```/form``` endpoint along with a data payload that describes the form you wish to create. The URL is as follows.

```
POST - https://myproject.form.io/form
```

request.description: This will retrieve a single submission within a form.
This is a quick API call to see if a record exists. This check can be performed anonymously, and no data is actually sent back to the client. Just a confirmation if the record exists or not (404)

item.name: Get all submissions within a form

request.description:
To **read multiple** submissions at once, perform a **GET** request against a resource's submission URL. The submission URL has an additional querystring to limit the number of items and a Range header to iterate over multiple pages.

###To query for specific submissions###
In order to find specific submissions within the index, you can also perform queries for any poperty within a submission. A typical submission is as follows.

```
{
    "_id": "57cf908e6605476b00fab81f",
    "modified": "2016-09-07T03:59:10.836Z",
    "data": {
        "firstName": "Joe",
        "lastName": "Smith",
        "email": "joe@example.com",
        "phoneNumber": "234234234"
    },
    "form": "57c6d2a1783e146f00bc65c4",
    "created": "2016-09-07T03:59:10.818Z",
    "externalIds": [],
    "access": [],
    "roles": ["57c6d2a1783e146f00bc65c2"],
    "owner": "553dbfc08d22d5cb1a7024f2"
}
```

Where the submission data can be found within the ```data``` object. So, lets say you wish to find all people in the submissions who have the last name of Smith, you would run the following query.

```
{{appUrl}}/register/submission?data.lastName=Smith
```

In addition to using ```=``` you can use a number of other parameters and search criteria to fully refine your search. These parameters are as follows.

| Filter                       | Query    | Example                                              | Description                                                      |
|------------------------------|----------|------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **equal**                    | `equals` | `/submission?data.gender=male` 			                     | both return all male users                                       |
| **not equal**                | `ne`     | `/submission?data.gender__ne=male`                             | returns all users who are not male (`female` and `x`)            |
| **greater than**             | `gt`     | `/submission?data.age__gt=18`                                  | returns all users older than 18                                  |
| **greater than or equal to** | `gte`    | `/submission?data.age__gte=18`                                 | returns all users 18 and older (age should be a number property) |
| **less than**                | `lt`     | `/submission?data.age__lt=30`                                  | returns all users age 29 and younger                             |
| **less than or equal to**    | `lte`    | `/submission?data.age__lte=30`                                 | returns all users age 30 and younger                             |
| **in**                       | `in`     | `/submission?data.gender__in=female,male`                      | returns all female and male users                                |
| **nin**                      | `nin`    | `/submission?data.age__nin=18,21`                              | returns all users who are not 18 or 21                           |
| **exists=true**              | `exists` | `/submission?data.age__exists=true`                            | returns all users where the age is provided.                     |
| **exists=false**             | `exists` | `/submission?data.age__exists=false`                           | returns all users where the age is not provided.                 |
| **Regex**                    | `regex`  | `/submission?data.username__regex=/^travis/i`                  | returns all users with a username starting with travis           |

To **read multiple** submissions at once, perform a **GET** request against a resource's submission URL. The submission URL has an additional querystring to limit the number of items and a Range header to iterate over multiple pages.

###To query for specific submissions###
In order to find specific submissions within the index, you can also perform queries for any poperty within a submission. A typical submission is as follows.

```
{
    "_id": "57cf908e6605476b00fab81f",
    "modified": "2016-09-07T03:59:10.836Z",
    "data": {
        "firstName": "Joe",
        "lastName": "Smith",
        "email": "joe@example.com",
        "phoneNumber": "234234234"
    },
    "form": "57c6d2a1783e146f00bc65c4",
    "created": "2016-09-07T03:59:10.818Z",
    "externalIds": [],
    "access": [],
    "roles": ["57c6d2a1783e146f00bc65c2"],
    "owner": "553dbfc08d22d5cb1a7024f2"
}
```

Where the submission data can be found within the ```data``` object. So, lets say you wish to find all people in the submissions who have the last name of Smith, you would run the following query.

```
{{appUrl}}/register/submission?data.lastName=Smith
```

In addition to using ```=``` you can use a number of other parameters and search criteria to fully refine your search. These parameters are as follows.

| Filter                       | Query    | Example                                              | Description                                                      |
|------------------------------|----------|------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **equal**                    | `equals` | `/submission?data.gender=male` 			                     | both return all male users                                       |
| **not equal**                | `ne`     | `/submission?data.gender__ne=male`                             | returns all users who are not male (`female` and `x`)            |
| **greater than**             | `gt`     | `/submission?data.age__gt=18`                                  | returns all users older than 18                                  |
| **greater than or equal to** | `gte`    | `/submission?data.age__gte=18`                                 | returns all users 18 and older (age should be a number property) |
| **less than**                | `lt`     | `/submission?data.age__lt=30`                                  | returns all users age 29 and younger                             |
| **less than or equal to**    | `lte`    | `/submission?data.age__lte=30`                                 | returns all users age 30 and younger                             |
| **in**                       | `in`     | `/submission?data.gender__in=female,male`                      | returns all female and male users                                |
| **nin**                      | `nin`    | `/submission?data.age__nin=18,21`                              | returns all users who are not 18 or 21                           |
| **exists=true**              | `exists` | `/submission?data.age__exists=true`                            | returns all users where the age is provided.                     |
| **exists=false**             | `exists` | `/submission?data.age__exists=false`                           | returns all users where the age is not provided.                 |
| **Regex**                    | `regex`  | `/submission?data.username__regex=/^travis/i`                  | returns all users with a username starting with travis           |

header.name: Access-Control-Allow-Origin
header.description: Specifies a URI that may access the resource. For requests without credentials, the server may specify '*' as a wildcard, thereby allowing any origin to access the resource.

header.name: Access-Control-Expose-Headers
header.description: Lets a server whitelist headers that browsers are allowed to access.

header.name: Connection
header.description: Options that are desired for the connection

header.name: Content-Encoding
header.description: The type of encoding used on the data.

header.name: Content-Length
header.description: The length of the response body in octets (8-bit bytes)

header.name: Content-Range
header.description: Where in a full body message this partial message belongs

header.name: Content-Type
header.description: The mime type of this content

header.name: Date
header.description: The date and time that the message was sent

header.name: Link
header.description: Used to express a typed relationship with another resource, where the relation type is defined by RFC 5988

header.name: Range-Unit
header.description: Custom header

header.name: Server
header.description: A name for the server

header.name: Vary
header.description: Tells downstream proxies how to match future request headers to decide whether the cached response can be used rather than requesting a fresh one from the origin server.

header.name: X-Powered-By
header.description: Specifies the technology (ASP.NET, PHP, JBoss, e.g.) supporting the web application (version details are often in X-Runtime, X-Version, or X-AspNet-Version)

header.name: x-jwt-token
header.description: Custom header

item.name: Find a user by form field

request.description: Many times you will need to perform a search within form submissions to find a specific record. This can be done using our Search API. This allows you to search any field within a specific form based on the value of the item you are looking for. To search on any value within the submission, simply provide ```data.FIELD_API``` as the query parameter, where ```FIELD_API``` is the ***API Key*** of the field.

originalRequest.description: Many times you will need to perform a search within form submissions to find a specific record. This can be done using our Search API. This allows you to search any field within a specific form based on the value of the item you are looking for. To search on any value within the submission, simply provide ```data.FIELD_API``` as the query parameter, where ```FIELD_API``` is the ***API Key*** of the field.

item.description:
The Submission API gives you access to create, submit, edit, delete, and search submissions within a form.

This also includes User creation authentication since all users are simply considered resources within the project.

item.name: 5.) Report API
item.description: ***NOTE: You must have at least a Team Pro project to use the Report API*** The Report API can be accessed through the URL path of ```/report``` within your project. So, as an example, if your project API url is ```https://myproject.form.io```, then the report API for that project is ```https://myproject.form.io/report```. This endpoint can be used with a payload of the MongoDB Aggregation Pipeline to create the report you need. As an example, lets say you have multiple Forms, where all of them provide a Status field. Using the Report API, you can generate a Report to determine the count of each status within multiple forms within your project. The MongoDB Aggregation pipeline for this query would look something similar to the following.

request.description: This request will delete a specific submission within a form.

To delete a specific form, you simply use the ```DELETE``` method against the URL of the form as follows.

```
DELETE - https://myproject.form.io/myform
```

originalRequest.description:
To delete a specific form, you simply use the ```DELETE``` method against the URL of the form as follows.

```
DELETE - https://myproject.form.io/myform
```

request.description: This command will delete an application administrator.
This request will delete a project created within Form.io.
